title: 113_s2874
content: The Act titled "Prohibiting Detention of Youth Status Offenders Act of 2014" aims to deinstitutionalize status offenders. Section 223 of the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to address the placement of juveniles in secure detention or correctional facilities for violating orders. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to address the placement of juveniles in secure detention facilities for violating court orders. The court must issue a written order identifying the violated court order, providing the factual basis for the violation, and stating that there is no less restrictive alternative available. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to address the placement of juveniles in secure detention facilities for violating court orders. The court must issue a written order specifying the length of time, not to exceed 3 days, that the juvenile may remain in the facility, including a release plan, and prohibiting renewal or extension of the stay. The court must issue a written order specifying the length of time, not to exceed 3 days, that a juvenile may remain in a secure detention facility for violating court orders. Procedures are in place to ensure the juvenile does not stay longer than 3 days or the time authorized by the court or state law. Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this subsection, no State receiving a formula grant under this part may use a valid court order to place a juvenile status offender in a secure detention facility or secure correctional facility, unless hardship is demonstrated and approved by the Administrator. State receiving formula grant must not use court order to place juvenile status offender in secure facility without demonstrating hardship. Application for 1-year extension can be submitted with progress report and compliance plan.
